items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.94m AOD at 04:00 on 21/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 34 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Overtopping waves and spray are expected on Wednesday evening (20/10/21) between 6pm and 7.45pm, as a result of spring tides and strong winds. The areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Kilnsea Village, however strong winds may generate wave and windblown spray affecting exposed coastal areas and roads between these times. Please be careful along exposed footpaths and roads as waves and overtopping spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Thursday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 23:45 and 01:45 tonight, Wednesday 20 October, into the morning of Thursday 21 October. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.77 mAODN at 00:45, Thursday 21 October, which is 0.26m above tide tables, wind Force 6, Northley. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and expect to re-issue this message for the following tide, afternoon of Thursday 21 October.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21 October.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels have risen on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected later this morning 20/10/21, especially in the Lower Stratton area. 
Further heavier rainfall is forecast this morning, with additional light showers possible through the rest of today. We expect river levels to begin rising imminently.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 20/10/21, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning 20/10/21, especially in the Passfield area. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 20/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected between 12pm and 6pm this evening, 20/10/2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield and Penshurst and low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further showers are expected throughout today with heavy rainfall forecast overnight between 6pm until 6am on 21/10/2021. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow afternoon, 21/10/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated this evening, 20/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Asker, River Brit, River Bride, River Char, River Lim

items.message:
River levels remain high in the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to the heavy rainfall last night.  
Further rainfall is forecast for this evening and overnight which can cause river levels to rise rapidly.  River levels are likely to be at their highest between 9:30 PM on the 20/10/21 until 4:00AM on the 21/10/21.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.  Consider activating any property flood protection products if available.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12:00AM on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high in the Upper Dorset Frome and the Hooke River.  Therefore low lying land will continue to be affected around the tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester.  
Further rainfall is forecast for this evening and overnight which can cause river levels to rise rapidly.  River levels are likely to be at their highest between 11:30 PM on the 20/10/21 until 5:00AM on the 21/10/21.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.  Consider activating any property flood protection products in Maiden Newton if available.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 12:00 AM on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Wednesday 20th October, and into Thursday morning. Yesterday’s heavy rain has caused river levels to rise and we expect these to remain high throughout today. Further heavy rainfall is expected this evening and into the early part of the night. Rivers are likely to rise quickly in response to this rainfall. 
This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from this evening Wednesday 20th October and into Thursday morning. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Little Alne river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 14:00 this afternoon, 20/10/21. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this afternoon and evening, 20/10/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated this afternoon, 20/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Gurnard Luck is high and rising. In the last 12 hours, 30mm of rain has been recorded in Cowes. This is a large amount in a short period of time. High tide at Cowes is at 11:45 this morning (20/10/21).  The river will rise for 3 hours after high water (until 14:45) before the river can drain with the lowering tide. Properties nearest to the river in Marsh Road may experience garden flooding throughout this period. Further rain is forecast later this afternoon and overnight with between 20 to 40mm expected. At high tide tonight (23:55 on 20/10/21) and tomorrow lunchtime (12:20 on 21/10/21), river levels could be similar or slightly higher than experienced today. Garden flooding may therefore occur for several hours over each high water. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will keep the river clear of reported blockages. Until water levels fall with each lowering tide, please keep away from the river at Gurnard Road Bridge.  Water will be deep and fast flowing. This message will be updated by 16:00 on Thursday 21/10/2021.

items.description: South Cornwall coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the evening high tide on Wednesday 20 October. High water at Truro is at 18:16 on Wednesday. Times of high water will vary along the coast. 

Unsettled weather and large waves combined with spring tides may cause flooding and wave over-topping of low-lying coastal areas exposed to southerly storms. 

Communities particularly at risk include Mevagissey, Portmellon, Maenporth and low-lying properties in the areas of the Helford Estuary and Penryn River.  Tides are expected to be around 0.3m higher than predicted on tide timetables and wave heights, up to 1.9m due to weather conditions. 

Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. 

We are closing locks and flood gates in the area. We will continue to monitor the forecast. This message will be updated by Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 6:30 and 8:30am on Thursday 21st October.  We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 4.07mAODN at 7:30am, on Thursday 21st October, which is 1.03m above tide tables, wind Force 7, NW. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation, and do not currently expect to re-issue this message for the following tides.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 6:30 and 8:30am, Thursday 21st October.   We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 4.07 mAODN at 7:30am, on Thursday 21st October, which is 1.03m above tide tables, wind Force 7, NW. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation, and do not currently expect to re-issue this message for the following tides. We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October.

items.description: South Devon coast from Start Point to Dawlish Warren
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water on Wednesday at Teignmouth is at 19:45, times of high water will vary along the coast. 
Large wind and wave conditions are not expected, however water levels are expected to be high. Expect tides to be up to 0.29m higher than predicted due to weather conditions. 
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast. 
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required. 
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Teignmouth on Wednesday at 19:45 is 2.44 mAOD, this is 0.29m above astronomical tide level.

Thursday's early morning tide at 00:30 on 21/10/2021 will be very similar to Thursday afternoon's. Tides are higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 Northerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.34 m. The total forecast tide is 6.11 metres Chart Datum (3.06 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, wave overtopping will affect the beach front. A small amount of water may pond on nearby land, fields and at Climping Street Car Park and could flow or be directed westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards residential property in Climping Street. Tide conditions are forecast to be similar until Friday 22/10/2021. Thursday afternoon's tide is likely to be slightly (20cm) higher than Wednesday afternoon's. We continue to monitor the forecast. We may check the condition of the beach at low tide. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 11:00 on 21/10/2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible Wednesday evening and overnight into the early hours of Thursday morning. Over the last 24 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Devon area, and we are expecting more rainfall showers throughout today and overnight.

We expect the river levels to remain high throughout Wednesday and overnight, and river levels are expected to start falling late Thursday morning. 

Flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers is expected. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages in this location. This message will be updated on Thursday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Wednesday 20th October. Rivers are rising steadily in response to overnight rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October.

items.description: The River Glaven through Hunworth, Thornage and Letheringsett
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low-lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely through today, Wednesday 20th October. The River Glaven is rising steadily in response to overnight rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying roads and riverside areas in Letheringsett, Little Thornage and Glandford. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October.

The River Mun is rising steadily in response to overnight rainfall. Areas most at risk are in Mundesley around Water Lane. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.41m AOD at 03:00 on 21/10/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington low for this time of year at 34 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of a low pressure surge and strong North-Westerly Winds.  
Tides will be at their highest at 07:30 tomorrow morning, Thursday 21 October 2021. 
Flooding along coastal areas is possible at this time, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton.   
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.85 mAODN. 
The forecast surge height is 0.85 m. The forecast tide level is 4.70 mAOD. 
The forecast wind direction is North-Westerly. 
The forecast wind strength is Force 7.
We are closely monitoring the situation and provided updates to this information, when required.
This message will be updated at 17:00 on Wednesday 20th October 2021.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual as a result of a low pressure surge and strong North-Westerly Winds.  
Tides will be at their highest at 07:30 tomorrow morning, Thursday 21 October 2021. 
Flooding along coastal areas is possible at this time, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  
We expect flooding to affect Hunstanton seafront.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it: the predicted astronomical tide level is 3.85 mAODN. 
The forecast surge height is 0.85 m. The forecast tide level is 4.70 mAOD. 
The forecast wind direction is North-Westerly. 
The forecast wind strength is Force 7.
Please note the Local Authority are closing the flood gates at Hunstanton which will make access difficult.
We are closely monitoring the situation and provided updates to this information, when required.
This message will be updated at 17:00 on Wednesday 20th October 2021.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening, Wednesday 20th October, and into Thursday morning, especially in the smaller urban watercourses. Yesterday’s heavy rain has caused river levels to rise. Further heavy rainfall is expected this evening and into the early part of the night. Smaller watercourses, especially in urban areas, are likely to rise quickly in response to this rainfall. This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from this evening Wednesday 20th October and into Thursday morning. However, flooding to properties is not currently expected. 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

Thursday's early morning tide at 00:15 on 21/10/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 South Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.4 m. The total forecast tide is 7.66 metres Chart Datum (4.01 mAOD) at Eastbourne. For 2 hours either side of high water, beach top properties at Pevensey Bay will be affected by spray, caused by the large waves. The road at Herbrand Walk may flood, and could be impassable to traffic. Thursday afternoon's tide is forecast to be 20cm higher, but with slightly smaller waves, which could generate similar impacts again. Tide levels should fall from Friday (22/10/2021). We continue to monitor the forecast. To protect property from flooding, at low tide, Pevensey Coastal Defence Ltd will maintain the condition of the shingle beach. Avoid Pevensey beach at high tide. Spray and waves will contain and scatter shingle which is dangerous. As a precaution, plan driving routes to avoid Herbrand Walk. We will update this message by 11:00 on  Thursday 21/10/2021.

Thursday morning's tide at 11:45 on 21/10/2021 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light North Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.32 m. The total forecast tide is 5.26 metres Chart Datum (2.52 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. After this tide‚ only minimal further impacts are expected for the rest of the week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on Thursday 21/10/2021.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 23:45 and 01:45 tonight, Wednesday 20 October 2021 (night) into morning of Thursday 21 October 2021. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50 mAODN at 00:45, on Thursday 21st October, which is 0.40m above tide tables, wind Force 6, N (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). We are monitoring the situation, take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We expect to re-issue this message for the following tide, on Thursday afternoon.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21 October 2021.

items.description: River Avon from Didworthy to Aveton Gifford
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The river levels are now dropping in the River Avon, however we expect further heavy rainfall today and overnight, on Wednesday 20th October, which may again trigger flood warnings. A Flood Alert still remains in force for the South Devon Rivers area, and we may see flooding of low-lying land and roads. We will continue to monitor the situation and will provide an update should the situation change.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Heavy rainfall has triggered local rainfall alarms. The Environment Agency believes that based
on the intensity and amount of rainfall, properties are at immediate risk of flooding along Priory
Road, Swans Ghyll, Riverside and Blenheim Fields. If you have them, activate your property
protection measures now. Flooding is expected imminently.

Due to some unexpected intense rainfall earlier in the evening river levels have risen quickly at the Maiden Newton river gauge. Consequently we are expecting possible flooding of property.  
There is further rainfall due for the next few hours, some of which could be heavy.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please can owners with property flood resilience equipment install it now and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 20/10/21, or as the situation changes

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:30pm and 03:30am tomorrow morning, Thursday 21st October 2021. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the Fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.46 mAODN at 1:30am, on Thursday 21st October 2021, which is 0.59m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North West (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October 2021.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast at Wells Quay
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 5:30 and 9:30am on Thursday 21st October.   Areas most at risk are The Quay, East End and roads joining the Quay between the Flood Barrier and East End including, Unns Yard, Jicklings Yard, Staithe Street, Croft Yard and Standard Street. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 4.07 mAODN at 7:30am, on Thursday 21st October, which is 1.03m above tide tables, wind Force 7, NW. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation, and do not currently expect to re-issue this message for the following tides.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Thursday 21st October.
